Rumbold

Saint Rumwold (Rumbold) was a medieval infant saint in England, said to have lived for three days in 662. He is said to have been full of Christian piety despite his young age, and able to speak from the moment of his birth, requested baptism, and delivered a sermon prior to his early death. Another Saint Rumbold (Rumold, Romuold) (died 775) was an Irish or Scottish Christian missionary who was martyred near Mechelen by two men, whom he had denounced for their evil ways.

Their patois
Of course the Citizen is at that very moment utilizing the said patois.
Coming over here to Ireland filling the country with bugs.
An unambiguous statement from the citizen that any emigrant to Ireland is subhuman. One of many in this chapter.
In the third week after the feastday of the Holy and Undivided Trinity

Trinity Sunday, which in the Roman Catholic calendar falls on the Sunday after Pentecost, often in early June.

“The Holy and Undivided Trinity” is a liturgical idiom.
Month of the oxeyed goddess
The oxeyed goddess is Hera, who became Juno in Roman mythology and thus, the source of the name for the month of June.
Didn’t serve any notice of the assignment on the company at the time and nominally under the act the mortgagee can’t recover on the policy

Though the narrator’s recounting is garbled with mockery and probably a lack of understanding, it appears Bloom believes that Dignam’s widow is to receive life insurance proceeds and that the lender holding a mortgage on the Dignam house cannot get to the insurance money to satisfy the mortgage debt because Dignam did not put the insurance up as collateral for the mortgage.

Bloom wants to discuss this question with Martin Cunningham.
Sinn Fein amhain!
“Ourselves alone.”
The invincibles and the old guard and the men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight

A quick summary of Feinians, referencing the 1867 Fenian Rising (a failed rebellion) and the poem “The Memory of the Dead” by John Kells Ingram

https://www.bartleby.com/246/214.html

The Citizen references the poem again in a few paragraphs.
Ruling passion strong in death
A quotation from Alexander Pope’s “The Ruling Passion” (1708)
